title: Before 1 July 2018, will a date be set for a referendum on Northern Ireland's governance status?
preds: The threat of a vote is more effective than having a vote. Northern Ireland gets too much cash from the UK. Irish voters would not be willing to subsidize NI, NI voters would not want to have to lose the UK subsidies, Ireland would probably not welcome having a significant (12%?) minority of people who would resent being Irish.

Perhaps POME’s should engage Harry Potter for some magical thinking on the border.
https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/apr/05/little-progress-from-magical-thinking-in-brexit-talks-on-irish-border

In the face of Brexit, Northern Ireland faces many questions both socially and economically. Like Scotland, Northern Ireland voted to stay in the EU in the 2016 referendum. UK 'Brexiteers' have made it clear that Northern Ireland's shared border with the Republic of Ireland will a a 'hard' one, signaling that strict trade regulations which will be damaging for both country's economies. With clear desire to stay in the EU and increased social pressure for the reunification of Ireland, a referendum date must be set in the immediate future.

The question isn't .. will a referendum be won; nor even will  referendum be voted on. 
Its will a date be set.   They could set a date even without expecting to win the referendum. I rate the decision around 9%.  Low enough to go all in.
Northern Ireland's governance status seems to be the one thing Theresa May is adamant about....N.Ireland sticks with the UK.

Extremely unlikely to happen within this timeframe, but a catastrophic failure to resolve the Irish border issue (especially if Brexit brings down the Conservative Government and puts Labour's Jeremy Corbyn in power) could lead to this outcome eventually.
Too close to the 102nd anniversary of the hanging of Protty-born (but later allegedly baptised by rc priest)  Irish nationalist martyr Roger Casement, formely Sir Roger Casement CMG ;)
Seems everyone is going 0% bar a few 65% and 90%. Would like to read the comments from those.  Voter fatigue for me. Might be at 5% if it was December 31 2018 timeline.

After the last speech of Theresa May, it is clear that they want to avoid a hard border on the Irish Island. I maintain that later (if Brexit negotiations run out of time and fail) this could be an issue, but not until July.
Despite the increase in Northern Irish people seeking reunification there are still too many variables and issues not being addressed.

With Mrs May rejecting the wording of the document by the EU has drawn up to put the Brexit Leaving agreement into full legal form, on the grounds that in  paragraph 49  "full alignment with those rules" (in the 8th Dec document) does not mean "full legal alignment". Obviously Eire and the EU think it does mean "full legal alignment". It is possible that the EU, Eire and the citizens of NI may think the UK is not acting in good faith, especially as Brexiteers have also been saying that it does not really matter that much if there are customs checks on the Irish border. The UK government has made it much more likely that NI citizens may demand a referendum on their status. However it is likely that Mrs May will climb down in s few days or weeks (maybe the EU will change a word or two in the Withdrawal document.  In any event its unlikely that the UK could act fast enough set a date for a referendum by 1st July. (note: David Davis the UK's Brexit negotiator has not had time to meet Barnier his EU counterpart since November, in spite of there appearing to be lots that needs to be agreed.)  Extract of 8th Dec agreement
49. The United Kingdom remains committed to protecting North South cooperation and to its guarantee of avoiding a hard border. Any future arrangements must be compatible with  these  overarching  requirements.  The United Kingdom's  intention  is  to  achieve these objectives through  the overall EU UK relationship. Should this not be possible, the United Kingdom will   propose specific   solutions   to   address   the   unique 
circumstances  of  the  island  of  Ireland.  In  the  absence  of  agreed  solutions,  the United Kingdom will maintain full alignment with those rules of the Internal Market and the Customs Union which, now or in the future, support North-South cooperation, the all-island economy and the protection of the 1998 Agreement.

A surprising new intervention related to this question is that a number of hard-line Brexiteers (Kate Hoey, Owen Paterson, Daniel Hannan) have suggested that the Good Friday Agreement (that ended the "troubles" in Northern Ireland) should be set aside or unilaterally amended by the UK Government (slightly different stories from each of them reported in the media). On the face of it their desire for changing or scrapping the agreement is the current difficulty of forming a Northern Ireland  Government, but there is a strong suspicion is that their real motive is that the GFA creates a problem for Brexit (only Brexiteers have suggested that the GFA needs to be changed). It is the GFA that established, and continues to ensure, that the border between NI and Eire has no physical presence, which contradicts the UK Governments position that Brexit will mean leaving the Single Market and Customs Union, which legally means there must be a physical border between NI and Eire.  It is the GFA that also gives the voters of NI the right to hold a referendum on union with Ireland, so no GFA, no right to the referendum in this question. What would happen without the GFA (or a replacement agreed and approved by the people of NI) I don't know, but I suspect that not many people in Ireland and NI are in any hurry to find out.   The irony is that the GFA was put to a referendum on 1998 and 71% of of NI voters approved it.  What was put to voters, and overwhelmingly approved, was not a vague  idea for a peace deal, but a fully detailed peace deal that had taken years of negotiations. It is strange that the Brexiteers believe that the referendum on Brexit (no details, certainly no agreement yet 20 months after the referendum) won by a small margin represents "the will of the people", cannot be changed and no vote can be allowed on the final deal agreed, while the GFA referendum can be thrown out because it is inconvenient. I hope we do not need to wait for 20 years before "the will of the people" on Brexit can be reconsidered. Of course NI did not want Brexit either, but I guess that can be ignored. https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/20/ireland-kate-hoey-good-friday-agreement-remarks
https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2018/feb/21/mps-accuse-kate-hoey-of-putting-brexit-before-northern-ireland-peace

It appears that the inability to come to agreement regarding a power sharing government has monopolized attention away from the Brexit vote.  I see this chance of a date being set as dwindling.    https://www.irishnews.com/news/politicalnews/2018/02/14/news/stormont-talks-have-failed-and-there-is-no-prospect-of-a-deal-says-dup-leader-arlene-foster-1256022/

The breakdown in talks to set up a government in N.I. is related to this question in complex ways e.g. the DUP is viewed by the nationalists as preventing devolved NI government, the lack of agreement on a  devolved NI government makes the current system of NI governance appear unworkable for the long term, if the current system does not work, then it opens up the question of what system would work, there are two obvious possible alternatives paths for NI - rule from London or a united Ireland. Both the DUP and UK government are less in control than they appear. The UK Government depends of Parliamentary support in Westminster from the DUP, so has no leverage over the DUP in creating a new devolved NI government. The DUP risks pushing opinion in the UK in general and in NI in particular towards the idea that a united Ireland would be less trouble that the status quo. For example a United Ireland would solve the Irish border problem that could wreck Brexit so Brexiteers might see the DUP as a Brexit block, but without the DUP May's government would fall so maybe there would be no Brexit. Liberal minded MP's in Westminster from all parties might question why if the DUP wants NI to remain part of the UK they are also insisting that NI is governed by social laws that are much more illiberal that the rest of the UK. (e.g. on abortion, minority languages etc.). 
But in the end all the unstable players in this mess are propping each other up; one falls and they all fall. So the safest thing to do is nothing.
Theresa May is not able ton influence it.

I think that any referendum will be as a consequence of a final Brexit deal. There will not be a deal prior to 1 July 2018, so it is highly unlikely that there will be a date set for a referendum. However, a certain small wildcard percentage is allowed, given the unusual and unstable nature of May's current governing coalition.

Brexit could be a reason. https://www.politico.eu/article/eu-issues-brexit-ultimatum-on-ireland/
Northern Ireland has three options (in theory):
1) the whole UK remains in the customs union - Theresa May does not prefer this, very unlikely
2) N.I. gets some special status inside the customs union - this is what the EU proposed, but DUP does not like this and is part of the London govt.
3) N.I. leaves the customs union together with the rest of the UK. This means the border is reinstalled between N.I. and the republic of Ireland. -  this latter is something that could trigger a referendum (and even violence). N.I. voted to remain in the EU (55%), which also suggests option 1 or 2 (politically, to avoid even more political problems, separation from the republic could unleash much more than a referendum), but as the negotiations are slow and unclear, it seems that the deadline will arrive before everything is settled. Thus, if nothing changes, the situation is gravitating towards option 3. The DUP probably is not in favor of option 1 and 2, but in Northern Ireland, they only have around 30% of the votes, which together with the 55% remainers shows, that starting a referendum campaign would not be a hopeless political experiment. The London government also knows this, they wont take another risk probably. However according to this brexit timeline: http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/02/01/timeline-road-brexit/ probably there will be no decision on Northern Ireland's status until the question deadline. So my conclusion is, that this could happen, but later more likely. Now apparently both the EU and the London government wants to avoid a political crisis in N.I. so despite DUP's opinion, I think they will somehow work out option 2. But because if negotiations fail option 3 will happen, I give it 3%.

They appear far too deadlocked to do something as complicated as hold a referendum. Dateline 2-12-2018  British Prime Minister Theresa May and Irish leader Leo Varadkar will meet with Northern Ireland’s main political parties in Belfast on Monday to urge the restoration of the province’s devolved administration. -- https://www.reuters.com/article/us-nireland-politics/british-irish-pms-to-visit-northern-ireland-urging-end-to-political-crisis-idUSKBN1FW00C

The only way Northern Ireland will make that announcement is if Scotland votes to leave the UK, which would make staying in less desirable. Scotland won’t do this for some time yet since they need to be certain they will win, and need to know the terms of Brexit in order to gauge that outcome.

The agreement says that, in the absence of another solution for the Border, the UK will maintain full regulatory alignment with those rules of the single market and the customs union which, “now or in the future, support North-South co-operation, the all-island economy and the protection of the 1998 agreement”.
https://www.irishtimes.com/news/politics/simon-coveney-sees-no-ambiguity-in-deal-on-post-brexit-border-1.3353525
Shifts towards a new Anglosphere structure (including UK, Ireland and other countries) will obviate the need for NI changes.
NIers want to know Brexit terms before making this choice
Brexit proceedings have remained slow, so progress that would precipitate this is conditional on more UK noise.
More likely a date set after July, 2018.

A year after the dissolution of the Northern Ireland Assembly, politicians remain unable to form government.
https://www.foreignbrief.com/europe/trouble-northern-ireland-deadlock/
There will have to be some sort of referendum for a unification of Ireland set to ease the economic tensions set in Ireland counties by England leaving the EU.

I agree with @PlasticBinge reasons (below Jan 2nd) but I would add:
The link below outlines possible Brexit scenarios. The problem of what Brexit deal would keep the Irish border totally open is made clear, but the consequence of not keeping it open is not fully explored, but only considered in relation to the DUP support for the May government. If the UK proposes a deal with the EU that would result in a hard Irish border the polls show that most voters in N. I. would support the idea of a referendum to unite with Ireland. Bloomberg have considered what the DUP might do in that case, but have not considered that the DUP's views do not match the majority view of Brexit (most in N.I. were against Brexit) nor that the peace agreement requires that if the population demands it a referendum on a united Ireland must be held. The polls also show that if the Brexit deal would result in a hard Irish border and a referendum on a united Ireland were called it would (according to the recent polls) result in a united Ireland. This is regardless of the support for the political parties, and regardless of religious background. Breaking up the U.K. is not something that the Conservative Party of Mrs May would contemplate. For many of its voters that would be a worse outcome than no Brexit. 
So in my view the question of a united Ireland referendum is part of a row of dominoes; if May insists on leaving the EU Single Market and Customs Union a hard Irish border becomes certain; if there is a hard Irish border, N.I. would unite with Ireland and leave the UK (with the risk that Scotland would also leave the UK); the breakup of the UK is not what the Brexit supporters want; so the UK will not risk it happening. If N.I remains in the Single Market/Customs union in order keep the Irish border open, but the rest of the UK does not that will still lead to demands for a united Ireland (and for Scotland to have a similar deal.) 
So which ever way May's government approaches it, the logical contradictions do not allow both leaving the EU Single Market/Customs union and keeping an open border with Ireland.      https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-03/the-year-that-makes-or-breaks-brexit P.S. My experience of "problem solving" is that you should start by establishing what the "problem" is, not start by thinking about setting red lines on what "solutions" you want or don't want. So with Brexit a list of what the problems are with the status quo would be good idea. What is wrong with the existing "Freedom of Movement", what is wrong with the existing EU Trade deals, what is wrong with the ECJ?  What are the EU rules that cause problems? We know that the EU Single Market and Customs union allow an open border with Ireland (and the whole EU) but I have not heard much about the problems it currently causes. We are told that it prevents the UK making deals with third countries, but that problem could be solved by the EU making deals with third countries (as it is with Canada and Japan and has with South Korea, as has been discussed with India, USA, Australia & New Zealand etc.) Many say that Brexit is really a vote against "Freedom of Movement" but some say its too many EU migrants, some say its the wrong sort of migrants. The EU Freedom of Movement rules allow for restrictions in cases of social or economic problems, so why is the UK not explaining what its problem is and looking to deal with that? If there are bad EU rules lets know what they are so they can be discussed, maybe other EU countries also think they are bad. If as a Systems Analyst and Systems Designer I had approached Brexit in the way that the UK Government has I suspect I would not have completed any successful projects.

Aside from Brexit - it would seem extremely unlikely. While demographic trends may mean it's more likely in future, for now, it seems that the unionist community ounumbers the nationalist community (albeit with a growing number who don't identify with either community).  Brexit could create a situation where some additional Northern Ireland citizens feel it would be advantageous to break away from the UK, however, as I understand it, brexit negotiations are likely to be ongoing on July 1st 2018 (they'll need to be finished well before Spring 2019). Until, negotiations are complete, and people have a chance to react to the final deal, the sectretary of state couldn't think it likely that a majority of voters would want out of the UK.  If the question date was '31st Dec 2018' - it should increase the probabilty somewhat. For it to happen by July, I guess the secretary of state would have to agree to name a date as part of the Brexit negotiation.. I don't think this is something the EU or Ireland would be pushing for - unless it ends up as a possible solution to a deadlock on the UK-Ireland border question. Even then, naming an actual date wouldn't have to be done before July 2018. (It just needs to be early enough to allow it to happen well before the date of Brexit iitself - end of March 2019).   Putting that thinking into a percentage...It's probably less than 1%. Potentially closer to zero.

According to the Irishnews article... "The authority to call a border poll rests with Secretary of State James Brokenshire, who shall exercise the power "if at any time it appears likely to him that a majority of those voting would express a wish that Northern Ireland should cease to be part of the United Kingdom and form part of a United Ireland"." Despite the fact that 56% of the Northern Irish vote was to remain within the EU, I don't see this as a large enough majority to call the Poll.  Additionally, remaining in the EU is very different that unifying Ireland.  Brokenshire would have to weigh the massive complexities of integration with the Republic of Ireland with the massive complexities of Brexit.  It appears to me that Brexit is sightly more palatable than integration.   http://www.irishnews.com/news/2017/03/11/news/are-we-any-closer-to-a-border-poll--960596/
UK is focused almost myopically on Brexit and anything that threatens  to derail the plan or even that focus will be ignored
I rather judge that there will be set a second vote on Brexit execution, rather than on this single very issue.
The question should be will the UK government allow a referendum?

Dateline 12-13-2017 In the early hours of Friday morning, as British Prime Minister Theresa May was driven home from Downing Street to catch two hours of sleep ahead of her dash to Brussels, an opinion poll was published in Northern Ireland. It reported a sensational result. For the first time, a majority in Northern Ireland (51 percent after factoring out undecideds, nonvoters, and spoilers) supported unification under the Irish Republic to remain in the European Union in the event of a “hard” Brexit. London’s “hard” Brexit plans, which entail leaving the EU’s internal market and customs union as well as its political structures, had caused the solid, pro-U.K. “Unionist” majority that had existed since Northern Ireland’s creation in 1921, to evaporate. The Good Friday Agreement of 1998 brought Northern Ireland’s sectarian conflict to an end and abolished the militarized frontier with the Republic of Ireland. The reintroduction of a hard border, staffed by customs officers managing the EU’s external boundary, would not just bring back memories of past violence, it would provide targets for Irish republican terrorists at which to aim.  -- http://foreignpolicy.com/2017/12/13/theresa-may-just-negotiated-away-the-united-kingdom/

In a set of polls conducted in December 2017 in Northern Ireland the the majority (excluding don't knows) would be in favour of a border poll on the status of NI if there is no deal on Brexit with the EU, and if that poll took place most would prefer uniting with Eire and staying in the EU, to remaining in the UK and leaving the EU. 
The UK failing to have any Brexit deal with the EU is not very likely (5% to 10% chance?) and its likely that negotiations will still be taking place when this question ends, so its very unlikely that this question will be "Yes". However the risk (as far as the UK Government would see it) of having NI leave the UK in the event of  a Brexit No-Deal will be another incentive to try very hard to get a Brexit deal. (The only Brexit deal that is likely to be on offer is for the UK to leave the EU but remain in the Single Market and Customs Union - I have just re-read the phase 1 agreement document and can see no other way to meet the 1998 NI Peace Agreement obligations as described in the phase 1 agreement; the UK has agreed to the  alignment of NI, UK and EU laws for far more than just cross border trade.) "   The United Kingdom remains committed to protecting and supporting continued North-South and East-West cooperation across the full range of political, economic, security, societal and agricultural contexts and frameworks of cooperation, including the continued operation of the North-South implementation bodies."
"The United Kingdom remains committed to protecting North-South cooperation and to its guarantee of avoiding a hard border. Any future arrangements must be compatible with these overarching requirements. The United Kingdom's intention is to achieve these objectives through the overall EU-UK relationship. Should this not be possible, the United Kingdom will propose specific solutions to address the unique circumstances of the island of Ireland. In the absence of agreed solutions, the United Kingdom will maintain full alignment with those rules of the Internal Market and the Customs Union which, now or in the future, support North-South cooperation, the allisland economy and the protection of the 1998 Agreement."

Ireland on the verge of snap election as crisis deepens Halpin (2017) November 27, states that: DUBLIN (Reuters) - Ireland was on the verge of a snap election on Monday after the opposition party propping up the minority government said the deputy prime minister’s refusal to quit would force the country to the polls next month. The political crisis that deepened dramatically late on Monday has left the country’s two main parties with less than 24 hours to head off a general election in a dispute that cast a shadow over a key Brexit summit next month Ireland will play a major role at the meeting, telling EU leaders whether it believes sufficient progress has been made on the future of the border between EU-member Ireland and the British province of Northern Ireland. The pressure on Deputy Prime Minister Frances Fitzgerald of Varadkar’s Fine Gael party mounted on Monday following the release of fresh documents about her disputed handling of a police whistleblower who alleged corruption in the force. Fianna Fail, whose backing Varadkar requires from the opposition benches to keep his government functioning, has said it will move a motion of no confidence in Fitzgerald at 2000 GMT on Tuesday unless she quits, a position that hardened on Monday (para. 1-5). Halpin, P. (2017). Ireland on the verge of snap election as crisis deepens. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-ireland-politics/ireland-on-the-verge-of-snap-election-as-crisis-deepens-idUSKBN1DR15P

If the EU/UK Brexit talks start to look as if they will result in a hard border being reinstated between Eire and Northern Ireland the public mood in N.I could change, and demands for a United Ireland could arise. As the UK economy in general and N.I. economy in particular seem to be heading for permanent low growth the risk of a United Ireland might seem more attractive. Clearly a united Ireland would not appeal to all in N.I. and a referendum would be very divisive, so the UK government would try and avoid anything that encourages the idea. For this reason the UK priority will be (ought to be) to avoid giving any reason for people in N.I. to think a United Ireland would be better than remaining in the UK. For that reason having an open border with Eire even if it means N.I. staying in the EU Customs Union is a lower risk than having a hard border. If Republicans don't like the Brexit deal they can campaign to resolve it by uniting with Eire; if the Unionists don't like the Brexit deal all they could do would be to allow May's UK government to fall, which would probably result in a new UK government without the DUP that would still not give the Unionists what they wanted. So regarding the Customs Union and N.I it seems to be "heads I win, tails you lose".
I think the real question will turn out to be does the whole UK remain in the EU Customs Union or is N.I, in and the rest of the UK out. That will be more difficult to square with the Brexit vote, as areas like Scotland and London will demand that they should not be made to suffer being out, when they voted to Remain.

Northern Ireland government is essentially at a standstill. PM May has bigger issues on her hands. If Corbin came to power, he might like to jettison Northern Ireland, but that unlikely to happen before mid-2018.

Northern Ireland's DUP warns of 'speedy' return to rule by London Graham (2017) August 31, states that: Irish nationalists Sinn Fein must reach out and compromise if Northern Ireland is to avoid a “speedy” return to direct rule from London, the head of the Democratic Unionist Party said on Thursday. Irish nationalists Sinn Fein and the DUP have failed to reach agreement on reforming a power-sharing government since a March election and each has blamed the other for missing repeated deadlines. Continued failure would force the British government to bypass the regional assembly and revert to direct rule from London for the first time in a decade, a move that could destabilize the political balance in the province. The British and Irish governments, who are facilitating the talks, have warned that failing to reach an agreement would have “profound and serious” implications and limit Northern Ireland’s influence in Brexit negotiations, although no one is forecasting a return to serious violence (para. 1-4). Graham, I. (2017). Northern Ireland's DUP warns of 'speedy' return to rule by London. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-nireland-talks/northern-irelands-dup-warns-of-speedy-return-to-rule-by-london-idUSKCN1BB2S4

Britain pushes for talks about the future, EU wants divorce first Baczynska and Blenkinsop (2017) August 27, states that: British officials arrive in Brussels on Monday to push the EU towards talks about their post-Brexit ties, which the bloc refuses to do without an agreement first on London’s exit bill and other divorce issues. A third round of Brexit talks takes place more than a year after Britons voted in a referendum to leave the European Union, delivering an unprecedented blow to the post-World War Two European integration (para 1-2). Britain will present in detail its several papers released last week on issues ranging from customs arrangements to data sharing. They have often ventured out into the future relationship between London and what will become a 27-state EU (para. 5). The bloc wants to settle chief separation aspects first and has already signaled the slow progress so far means jumpstarting talks about a new accord with Britain is now less likely in October, as had been expected (para. 8). The Irish issue, extremely delicate because of the violent history between the two communities there, is fraught with economic consequences and politically complex (para 12). On money, the EU and Britain seem to be seas apart on agreeing how much London should pay the bloc on departure to account for previous commitments. Sides expect no major leaps forward this week in the talks aimed at unraveling more than 40 years of union (para. 12-14). Baczynska, G. & Blenkinsop, P. (2017). Britain pushes for talks about the future, EU wants divorce first. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-idUSKCN1B70X5

Has 'ambitious' British PM aimed too high with EU demands? Piper (2017) August 24, states that: Prime Minister Theresa May always said she would be “ambitious” in negotiating Britain’s exit from the European Union, and government documents published this month show the scale of that ambition -- wanting the closest of ties without the costs. But the new British proposals for future ties with the EU have been dismissed in Brussels as “fantasy” and no more than an “intra-UK debate”. European officials have suggested that Britain should instead stick to a previously agreed timetable for Brexit negotiations. For Britain, the release over two weeks of a series of strategy and discussion documents was intended to counter criticism that it was unprepared for the talks, and to speed up negotiations that have moved slowly over the past 14 months (para 1-3). INTRA-UK DEBATE" After pointing to what he saw as lack of clarity on Britain’s future relationship with the European Court of Justice, a European Commission spokesman said: “You will not be surprised to hear me refraining from injecting myself into an intra-UK debate on their positions” (para 13). He and other EU officials said Brussels’ stance was the same: Britain should first focus on making progress on the three main issues in the initial phase of talks - the rights of expatriates, Britain’s border with EU member state Ireland, and a financial settlement (para 13-14). WARNING The gap in viewpoints in some areas - namely the financial settlement, role of the European court and future trade and customs arrangements - suggests talks next week between Barnier and British Brexit minister David Davis will be difficult and both sides have not set the bar high for progress (para. 21). Piper, E. (2017). Has 'ambitious' British PM aimed too high with EU demands? Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-idUSKCN1B4230
Very unlikely with the current situation in both the UK and Ireland.

http://www.independent.co.uk/voices/brexit-northern-ireland-only-practical-solution-a7898831.html "If you found the UK Government’s first Brexit “position paper” on avoiding a “cliff-edge” in trade borderline delusional, just try the second, on Northern Ireland. A lot of Irish magic will be needed if the proposals set out there are going to have any chance of success. "Three policies have commanded particular attention. On trade, most exchanges between Northern Ireland and the Republic would be regarded as local, and nothing to do with international rules at all. Except much hair-splitting about what constitutes small and medium-sized business. For the rest, tariff matters and payments would be handled by a whole new, hi-tech system – the UK’s track record of digital project management does not bode well. "As for the movement of people, well there would essentially be no need for change. Any risk that the Northern Irish-Republic of Ireland border could become a “back-door” into the UK (or vice versa) would be minimised because the Irish Republic is not – and would not be – a member of the Schengen, so the UK and Ireland could keep their own special passport-free regime, while keeping the outer borders secure. "Except that there are no passport or ID checks between the UK and Ireland, whatever sort of papers you carry. Indeed, the only way, travelling by road, you know you have crossed from the Republic into Northern Ireland is a sign saying that the speed limit is now posted in miles per hour. Any indication that you are crossing into another country is vanishingly discreet. Like it or not, there is a “back door” (which predates both countries’ EU membership). Whether this longstanding “special arrangement” can continue after Brexit is another matter. How feasible is a “soft” border between a member and non-member of the EU?
. . . 
The position with Northern Ireland is infinitely more difficult [than with Scotland]. And it was made more so because a majority of the Northern Irish voted to remain in the European Union. The margin (56 - 44 per cent) was not as sweeping as in Scotland (62 - 38 per cent), but it was solid. It was also bigger than the margin of victory for Leave in the UK as a whole (52-48), but also in England (53 - 47 per cent). "One reason why Northern Ireland, despite its unionist majority, voted more like Scotland than England or Wales may be that people on both sides of the sectarian divide saw EU membership as a kind of guarantee for the continuation of the Good Friday agreement that had (mostly) brought peace. Without the EU, the relatively relaxed relations with the Republic, the free movement of people and free trade across the border would all be called into question. "This is where we are now, with the UK trying desperately to hold on to the gains from EU membership as they relate to Northern Ireland, while preparing to break from the EU in almost every other respect. It is neither a logical nor comfortable position. . . .  "Happily – and unhappily – there is a solution, which is as simple and obvious as it is elusive. The one sure way to enshrine free movement, free trade, and regulatory clarity in relations between the two parts of Ireland is to put them back together. The North would thus remain in the EU – which is what a majority of those who took part in the referendum voted for – while the rest of the UK, aka Great Britain, would leave. The only border needed would be the sea. "How feasible would this be? Alas, despite the pro-EU vote in Northern Ireland, not at all – at least in the short term. The Northern Ireland parties may be finding it hard to form a new power-sharing government, now that the politicians who made peace have left the scene, and the unionist share of the vote may be declining, but a forced march to unity risks the peace. "The differences are not to be underestimated. From a distance, it is easy to condemn the recent clashes in the American south as “only” about a monument. But monuments – and flags – cannot be dismissed lightly. Over the decades they have sealed Ireland’s division. One person’s patriot is another’s traitor. The two communities remain fenced off from each other in Belfast and (London)Derry; if they find it so hard to share a city, how can they share a country? "And yet... Is it really beyond the bounds of wise statespeople to devise a solution? Would a clearly federated state not be possible; a state, what is more, with world-class guarantees for the rights of what would become the Protestant minority? Is the fear that would precipitate a resort to arms really still there? "Since the Brexit vote, the unity question has been very quietly, very tentatively, reopened, after 10 years in which the Good Friday Agreement had pronounced it closed. But a twist of fate – the Conservatives’ need for the DUP’s parliamentary votes – at once enhanced the status of the DUP in Northern Ireland and regrettably put any new thinking on hold. "But such an obvious remedy to the Brexit-Northern Ireland conundrum cannot remain off limits for ever. Demographic change in the North is already affecting elections there. Socially and economically, the Republic is a very different country from the one it was before it joined the EU. Arguably, the country that has changed least, in its institutional attitudes, is the UK. "If only it could fully accept the Republic of Ireland as an independent sovereign state, with no need for colonial-era privileges such as passport-free travel and votes in UK elections. If only it chose to halt the generous protection that stunts Northern Ireland’s development and allows a loyalist minority to live in the past. If the UK made moves in this direction, some of the biggest stumbling blocks in the Brexit negotiations would melt away – with the bonus of normalised relations between Great Britain and Ireland – even if, in the end, we decided not to leave.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I do not see a referendum being called prior to the actual Brexit.  Furthermore, while Sean Finn may want it, it's unlikely to pass in Northern Ireland because leaving the UK would mean an end to generous subsidies from Westminster for NI.

UK ready to pay up to 40 billion euros to leave EU: Sunday Telegraph Milliken (2017) Aug 5, states that: Britain is prepared to pay up to 40 billion euros ($47 billion) as part of a deal to leave the European Union, the Sunday Telegraph newspaper reported, citing three unnamed sources familiar with Britain's negotiating strategy. The European Union has floated a figure of 60 billion euros and wants significant progress on settling Britain's liabilities before talks can start on complex issues such as future trading arrangements. The government department responsible for Brexit talks declined to comment on the Sunday Telegraph article. So far, Britain has given no official indication of how much it would be willing to pay. The newspaper said British officials were likely to offer to pay 10 billion euros a year for three years after leaving the EU in March 2019, then finalize the total alongside detailed trade talks. Payments would only be made as part of a deal that included a trade agreement, the newspaper added. "We know (the EU's) position is 60 billion euros, but the actual bottom line is 50 billion euros. Ours is closer to 30 billion euros but the actual landing zone is 40 billion euros, even if the public and politicians are not all there yet," the newspaper quoted one "senior Whitehall source" as saying (para 1-6). The EU has also wants agreement by October on rights of EU citizens already in Britain, and on border controls between the Irish Republic and the British province of Northern Ireland, before trade and other issues are discussed (para. 13). Milliken, D. (2017). UK ready to pay up to 40 billion euros to leave EU: Sunday Telegraph. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-idUSKBN1AL0R1

Brexit web tangled by spats over how to leave, Irish border Faulconbridge and Milliken (2017) July 28, states that: Britain's progress towards life outside the European Union became more entangled on Friday, with divisions deepening over Northern Ireland's border and even the type of divorce Britain actually wants. The uncertainty coincided with the EU's top negotiator warning that formal talks are set to be delayed, eating up more of the two-year divorce timetable. Negotiations on the future relationship between Britain and the EU are now less likely to start in October because of a lack of progress at the initial stage of talks about the breakup, Brexit negotiator Michel Barnier has told EU ambassadors. Britain responded that it was confident that enough progress could be made to start the second stage of talks but as Prime Minister Theresa May holidayed in Italy, her ministers engaged in a public debate about how Brexit should look (para. 1-4). Brexit Transition Hammond's tone, meanwhile, is sharply different that of some other senior ministers in May's cabinet who want a cleaner break with the EU including swift controls on immigration (para. 14). "A transitional deal will delay all the benefits of being able to control our laws, trade and borders. We need to get on with it," said Richard Tice, a Brexiteer who helped fund one of the Leave campaigns in the EU referendum (para. 14-15). The proposals could be read to mean that Britain would continue to pay into EU coffers during the transition, continue to accept EU laws and even effectively accept its four freedoms allowing free movement of people, capital, goods and services (para. 21). Faulconbridge, G. & Milliken, D. (2017). Brexit web tangled by spats over how to leave, Irish border. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from 
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-idUSKBN1AD1I4

DUP warns of 'very hard border' over tougher Dublin stance on Brexit Halpin (2017) July 28, states that:  A senior member of the Northern Irish unionist party propping up British Prime Minister Theresa May's government warned on Friday that a hardening of Dublin's position on Brexit risked "a very hard border" returning to the island. The border between the Irish Republic, a member of the European Union, and the British province of Northern Ireland will be the only land frontier between the United Kingdom and the EU once Britain leaves the bloc in early 2019. Politicians in London, Dublin, Belfast and Brussels have all said they want to avoid the return of a "hard border" but Ian Paisley Jr of the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) warned of exactly that when he reacted strongly to a report that Dublin wanted the Irish Sea to effectively be the post-Brexit border. "1 of 2 things will now happen 1. A very hard border 2. Ireland will wise up and leave the EU," Paisley Jr, a member of the British parliament, said on Twitter, linking to the report in the Times newspaper. The report said the Irish government's preferred option for customs and immigration checks to be located away from the land border and at ports and airports instead would effectively draw a new border in the Irish sea. Officials from the Irish government agency responsible for customs checks said in May that such checks 10-15 kilometers from the frontier were being considered and then Irish finance minister Michael Noonan raised the possibility of control points at airports and ports over a year ago. Such a scenario would be unacceptable to the eurosceptic DUP which was the only major Northern Irish party to campaign for Brexit and which wants to boost the union with Britain in the face of calls by Northern Irish nationalists to unite both sides of the Irish border (para 1-7). Halpin, P. (2017). DUP warns of 'very hard border' over tougher Dublin stance on Brexit. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-ireland-idUSKBN1AD0KG

U.K. Resumes Brexit Talks With EU Douglas and Norman (2107) July 17, states that: The U.K. and the European Union began Brexit talks in earnest Monday, with a four-day negotiating session on a set of thorny issues the EU wants largely resolved before discussions turn to a future trade deal. U.K. Brexit Secretary David Davis and the EU’s top negotiator Michel Barnier returned to the negotiating table in Brussels for the first time since the official opening of talks on June 19, with the focus on U.K. and EU citizens’ rights after Brexit and how much London must pay to cover the U.K.’s outstanding financial commitments to the bloc. The two sides also are due to discuss how to manage the U.K.’s border with Ireland after withdrawal, expected in March 2019. The EU has insisted progress must be made on these and other separation issues before it will consider discussing future economic ties to the U.K., highlighting the challenge of agreeing a far-reaching settlement on Brexit within the 18 months remaining for talks (para. 1-4). Despite such differences, analysts say that the two sides should be able to reach a deal on citizens’ rights, but a much bigger disagreement looms over money (para. 8). The EU estimates the U.K. is on the hook for upward of €60 billion euros ($69 billion) in spending pledges made but not yet fulfilled. The prospect of payment on such a scale is political dynamite in the U.K., where advocates of Brexit won last year’s referendum in part on a promise to stop sending Brussels any money at all. Boris Johnson, U.K. foreign secretary, last week dismissed such demands as “extortionate” and agreed with a colleague in Parliament that the EU could “go whistle” for such a sum. Yet the U.K. government subsequently conceded in a written statement to Parliament that Britain is prepared to make “a fair settlement” with the EU and that it may keep making payments even after withdrawal. “Money is clearly going to be the stormiest dossier in phase one of the negotiations,” said Mujtaba Rahman, managing director at Eurasia Group (para. 8-13). Douglas, J. & Norman, L. (2107). U.K. Resumes Brexit Talks With EU. The Wall Street Journal. World. Europe. Retrieved from
Https://www.wsj.com/articles/u-k-resumes-brexit-talks-with-eu-1500303489

Rebels among UK's ruling Conservatives to scupper 'no-deal' Brexit: media O'Leary and Shakil (2017) Tue Jun 20, states that: Lawmakers in British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party believe they can stop Britain leaving the European Union without a deal if such a situation should arise, news media reported on Tuesday. The economic impact of a "cliff-edge" Brexit, alongside the failure of the Conservatives to win a majority in the general election, should lead to a rethink of the position that "no deal is better than a bad deal", Sky News reported, citing at least 30 Conservative lawmakers. Sky quoted a former minister saying "no deal is now dead", and anticipating a transition phase of five to 10 years inside the European Economic Area. May is eight seats short of a majority in Britain's parliament amid increasingly evident cracks in her own party just as crucial Brexit negotiations get under way. She sets out her policy plans in parliament on Wednesday without an arrangement giving her government enough support to pass legislation. She needs the support of Northern Ireland's Democratic Unionist Party (DUP), which is expected to use its 10 votes to back her in exchange for a series of agreements (para. 1-5). O'Leary, E. & Shakil, I. (2017). Rebels among UK's ruling Conservatives to scupper 'no-deal' Brexit: media. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-rebels-idUSKBN19B3A1

http://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-4619678/Commentary-Ireland--Theresa-Mays-latest-Brexit-blunder.html The Brexit vote, the loss of the Conservative majority in Parliament, May's proposal to form a coalition with the DUP (the only party to oppose Ireland's Good Friday Agreement), and the last-ditch negotiations in the power-sharing talks between the DUP & Sinn Féin in NI which, if unsuccessful in the next 9 days, will result in a return to direct rule of NI by London:  all have de-stabilized the situation in Northern Ireland which depends on an open border, power-sharing, and UK government impartiality.  In such a fluid situation, I think a less extreme forecast would be wise.

Britain is gearing up for EU disputes, Brexit minister says Piper (2017) Sun May 14, states that: Britain is gearing up for rows with the EU over the structure of divorce talks and the future role of the European court, fueling an increasingly bitter war of words before negotiations begin. David Davis, Brexit minister in Prime Minister Theresa May's government, described the EU's position on the talks' format as "illogical" and said he took "slight offense" to suggestions that European courts were better than those in Britain. The atmosphere between London and Brussels has soured in recent weeks as battle lines are drawn before the complex negotiations for Britain to leave the European Union are due to start next month, a year after June's referendum vote to quit. Asked about the EU's stance that the two sides should first make progress on citizens' rights, the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland and a financial settlement before starting discussions on a future relationship, Davis said the sequencing was "illogical". "How on earth do you resolve the issue of the border with Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland unless you know what our general borders policy is, what the customs agreement is, what the free trade agreement is, whether you need to charge tariffs at the border or not?" he asked on Britain's ITV (para. 1-6). Piper, E. (2017). Britain is gearing up for EU disputes, Brexit minister says
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-arguments-idUSKCN18A0D7

https://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/35472824/eus-barnier-says-wants-brexit-talks-without-aggressivity/#page1  Michel Barnier the EU's chief Brexit negotiator, " . . . .warned that Britain's departure from the EU would have "consequences", in particular for Ireland, raising the possibility of customs checks on the border with Northern Ireland.  . . .  Ireland has particular concerns about Brexit, focused on its strong trade ties with Britain and also its border with Northern Ireland -- the only EU-UK land border.  "I will work with you to avoid a hard border," Barnier told the joint session of the Houses of Oireachtas in Dublin. "But the Frenchman added: "The UK's departure from the EU will have consequences. We have together the duty to speak the truth. Customs controls are part of EU border management, they protect the single market, they protect our food safety and our standards.
But as I already said many times, nothing in this negotiation should put peace at risk, nothing."
. . . 
"Barnier repeated that the border issue was one of his three priorities for the Brexit talks, together with the rights of EU citizens living in Britain and London's exit bill.  "We first must make sufficient progress on these points before we start discussing the future of our relationship with the UK. And the sooner this will happen, the better, . . . If the conditions are right, a close partnership with the UK is in everybody's interests." "The Brexit vote has raised the prospect of a referendum on Northern Ireland reuniting with the Republic of Ireland, a provision which is included in the Good Friday Agreement but would require the consent of the British government. The EU has said that Northern Ireland would automatically become a European Union member state if it voted to unite with Ireland. "Gerry Adams, leader of the Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein, told Barnier in parliament that Northern Ireland should have "special designated status within the EU" even as the rest of Britain leaves. "Sinn Fein would like to see a referendum on Irish unity within the next five years," he said.
~~~~~~~

The EU text points to a clause in the 1998 Good Friday peace agreement that allows for a border poll to be called if a majority in Northern Ireland are likely to vote in favour of a united Ireland. “In this regard, the European Council acknowledges that in accordance with international law, the entire territory of such a united Ireland would thus be part of the European Union,” leaders said in the minutes to their meeting, which will not be approved until June.
http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/politics/taoiseach-says-referendum-on-united-ireland-is-not-currently-possible-35666105.html The Northern Ireland Act 1998, a statute of the Parliament of the United Kingdom, provides that Northern Ireland will remain within the United Kingdom unless a majority of the people of Northern Ireland vote to form part of a united Ireland. It specifies that the Secretary of State for Northern Ireland "shall exercise the power [to hold a referendum] if at any time it appears likely to him that a majority of those voting would express a wish that Northern Ireland should cease to be part of the United Kingdom and form part of a united Ireland". Such referenda may not take place within seven years of each other

EU to say united Ireland would be automatic full member Macdonald (2017) Fri Apr 28, states that: European Union leaders at a Brexit summit on Saturday should give a formal undertaking to embrace the British province of Northern Ireland in the EU if a referendum unites the island, diplomats said on Friday. Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny has previously asked fellow members of the bloc to acknowledge that Northern Ireland would, like East Germany in 1990, automatically enter the EU in the event of unification with the existing member state, the Irish Republic. Kenny will ask the other 26 leaders meeting in Brussels to endorse a negotiating plan for Britain's withdrawal to give a political endorsement to what Irish and EU legal experts say is the position in international law of such territorial changes. "It would merely state the obvious, i.e. that also a united Ireland would continue being a member of the EU," a source close to preparations for the European Council said. "The EU does of course not take a stance on the possibility of a united Ireland. Should this question arise, it would be for the peoples of Ireland and Northern Ireland to decide in accordance with the Good Friday Agreement."
The 1998 peace accord, backed by the British and Irish states, says referendums should be held on both sides of the border to approve unification of the island. The current British government has acknowledged that Northern Ireland, if it united with the Republic, should be in a position to rejoin the EU (para. 1-6). Macdonald, A. (2017). EU to say united Ireland would be automatic full member. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-eu-ireland-idUKKBN17U134

Northern Ireland power-sharing talks paused until after UK election Humphries (2017) Thu Apr 27, state that: Northern Ireland's main political parties have agreed to pause talks on forming a power-sharing government until after Britain's general election on June 8, the British government said on Thursday. The semi-autonomous Belfast government collapsed in January and despite fresh regional elections in March, Irish nationalists and pro-British unionists have failed to agree a deal to form a new executive. That has left Northern Ireland without political leadership as Britain prepares to start negotiations on exiting the European Union. The British government last week agreed to extend a deadline on forming a government until June 29 to avoid the risk of election campaigning derailing the talks. [nL8N1HT1OJ] On Thursday they agreed to pause talks during the campaign. "At round-table discussions ... it was agreed that formal talks to establish an Executive will be paused until after the General Election," Secretary of State for Northern Ireland James Brokenshire said in a statement (para. 1-5). Humphries, C. (2017). Northern Ireland power-sharing talks paused until after UK election. Reuters. World News. Retrieve from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-election-nireland-idUSKBN17T2CS

EU eyes years of Brexit payments, immigration: document Macdonald and Strupczewski (2017) Thu Apr 20, states that: Britain will be paying off obligations to Brussels for years after Brexit, remain subject to EU courts and go on letting relatives of European immigrants settle in the UK, draft EU negotiating documents show. The demands are contained in a paper, seen by Reuters on Thursday, that outlines "key elements" of directives for Michel Barnier, the EU's chief negotiator, who will launch talks on a Brexit treaty after Britain holds a general election on June 8. Prime Minister Theresa May has put ending "free movement" of workers from other EU states, budget contributions to Brussels and oversight by the European Court of Justice (ECJ) among central planks of her plans for leaving the European Union, due to happen in March 2019 after a two-year negotiating period. But in language that echoes a tough line taken by the 27 other EU leaders who will endorse a common position at a summit on April 29, the paper spells out Brussels' aim to protect the rights of 3 million EU citizens living in Britain, extract cash from London to cover a wide range of existing commitments and ensure EU judges can hold Britain to the treaty after Brexit. It does not put a figure on what Britain might owe -- May's ministers dismiss an estimate of 60 billion euros ($64 billion) floated by the EU -- but said the exit treaty should both set a "global amount" to honor financial obligations, subject to later adjustments. It will be fixed in euros, not pounds. And there would also be "a schedule of annual payments". That would reflect the fact that loans and guarantees made by the EU while Britain is a member extend well beyond 2019. During this transition period, rules would be enforced by the ECJ, the paper states, in one of numerous references to the Luxembourg judges' continuing role in Britain. It said the EU might consider an "alternative dispute settlement" system for the treaty, but only if that was "equivalent" to the ECJ. In a particularly pungent demand in a week where Brussels has slapped down London's claim that it might hang on to two EU agencies based in the capital, the paper says Britain should "fully cover ... costs" related to moving them and any other EU bodies to member states staying in the bloc (para. 1-9). Macdonald, A. & Strupczewski, J. (2017). EU eyes years of Brexit payments, immigration: document. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-britain-eu-negotiations-idUSKBN17M2HT

Fein demands new Northern Ireland elections if talks fail Humphries (2017) Fri Apr 7, states that: Northern Ireland should hold new elections if parties fail to reach agreement on forming a new government by a deadline next week, a senior member of Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein said on Friday, after a week of talks he said brought little progress. New elections would leave the British province without a government for two more months during Britain's crucial talks to exit the European Union, and would give Sinn Fein a chance to become the largest party in Northern Ireland for the first time. "The legislation is very clear: if there isn't an agreement we need to go to an election," said Conor Murphy, speaking to journalists on behalf of Sinn Fein's negotiating team. Northern Ireland has been in a political crisis since Sinn Fein pulled out of government in January, sparking a March 2 election that ended the majority which the pro-British unionists had enjoyed in the province for almost a century. Sinn Fein shocked many observers by getting very close to becoming the largest party in what would be a dramatic transformation of the province's politics. The British government last week extended a deadline until April 18 for Sinn Fein to reach agreement with pro-British rivals the Democratic Unionist Party (DUP) (para. 1-6). Humphries, C. (2017). Sinn Fein demands new Northern Ireland elections if talks fail. Reuters. World News. Retrieved from

The rules (it appears) are that the Secretary State for Northern Ireland shall call a border poll it at any time that it appears likely to him that the majority of those voting would express a wish that Northern Ireland should cease to be part of the UK and form part of a United Ireland. 
The Secretary of State is a UK Government Minister (in May's Government, appointed by May).  Opinion polls suggest that there is nothing approaching such a majority (it's more like 3 to 1 for staying in the UK). Realistically even if public opinion was closer to even May would probably do as she is doing regarding Scotland, i.e. tell NI that the time was not appropriate while Brexit was being negotiated  (which it will be presumable until at least the March 2019). 
In the event of a hard Brexit negatively affecting the border between Eire and NI, it not obvious that there would be an economic benefit to NI becoming part of a United Ireland. The Brexit problem is that traditionally people and goods have moved between Eire and the whole of the UK (as one market) but having all or part of Ireland in the EU, while the UK is outside the EU would create great problems for the movement of goods and people and the UK Government does not appear to have any idea how to mitigate the problem. (having no checks on the NI/Eire border as an open back door between the EU and UK, sounds problematic.)

I would say this is fairly likely. Sinn Fein will likely be able to drum up enough support to get a referendum on the ballot by the end of 2017. Scotland is going to move in a similar manner, especially now that Spain has said that they won't block an independent Scotland in the EU. As the specter of a hard Brexit grows, it should become increasingly possible that a referendum will be approved and have a date set.

UK raises prospect of direct rule for Northern Ireland if talks fail Humphries and Shirbon (2017) Tue Mar 28, states that: Britain will consider all options for Northern Ireland including direct rule from London if politicians there fail to form a regional government in the next three weeks, the minister for the province said on Tuesday. Northern Ireland politics has been in crisis since Irish nationalist party Sinn Fein pulled out of government in January, sparking a March 2 election that ended the majority pro-British unionists had enjoyed in the province for almost a century. The expiration on Monday of a three-week deadline to form a government raised fears that power might revert from the regional parliament to the British government in London, a step that took five years to reverse the last time it happened. "We do not want to see a return to direct rule," Northern Ireland minister James Brokenshire told the British parliament on Tuesday. "But should talks not succeed in their objective, the government will have to consider all options." If no agreement has been reached, the British parliament will begin to fill the power vacuum in Northern when it returns from its Easter recess on April 18 by bringing legislation to set local taxes on homes and businesses, he said. "Following the Easter recess, it would be my intention at a minimum to bring forward legislation to set a regional rate to enable local councils to carry out their functions," he said. "In the absence of the devolved government, it is ultimately for the UK government to provide political stability and good governance," he said (para. 1-6). Humphries, C. & Shirbon, E. (2017). UK raises prospect of direct rule for Northern Ireland if talks fail. Reuters. UK. Retrieved from
http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-britain-nireland-idUKKBN16Z1G0

The Nationalists don't have a majority in the Legislative Assembly, and would need to form a coalition to get the necessary votes. While approximately 55% of Northern Irish voted to stay in the EU, a September 2016 Ipsos MORI poll, 63% of Northern Irish indicated they would vote to remain a part of the UK if a border referendum vote were held. This poll was held between August and September 2016, over a month after the referendum vote to leave the EU (Brexit). While the Nationalists have made recent gains, and there are indications of an increasing sense of nationalism, there have not been sufficient indications that Sinn Fein can rally enough votes to for a successful referendum. While a date for a referendum could be announced without this support, it could potentially be a politically fraught decision for the Nationalists, with failure bolstering the support of the Unionists. Instead, they are likely to continue calling for a referendum "as soon as possible," while allowing time to observe the effects of Britain's Article 50 process and to continue building support for independence. With all that, the possibility exists that Northern Ireland could announce a date for a referendum before July 1, 2018. If the 2014 Scottish independence referendum serves as an example, it would take several months after the elections (about 8, in Scotland's case) to organize sufficiently to announce a date, followed by several years of preparation work before the actual referendum. And in the Scottish case, the Scottish National Party had won a majority of Parliament seats, thus gaining a mandate to hold the referendum. Sinn Fein does not have a mandate, even after the gains in the most recent election, and the next election is not scheduled until 2022. The July 1, 2018 date may be met if nationalist sentiment grows in the next several months, but based on the most recent, post-Brexit polling data, there is not sufficient interest by Northern Irish to leave the UK at this point. Therefore, I assess a 25% probability of Yes.
